cda:paragraph.cda:content: Chest Pain after Motor Vehicle Accident.
This is a 62-year old man with little history with medical establishment who was involved in a motor vehicle accident.
The patient was an unrestrained driver of a pickup truck that was rear-ended by another vehicle while stopped at a red light.
The other vehicle was moving at approximately 30 mph.
The patient was ambulating by the time of EMS arrival, however complained of neck and chest pain.
Patient hit the steering wheel, but the windshield was not starred and the steering wheel was intact.
The patient was admitted for overnight observation.

With a concern of chest paint, serial troponins and EKGs were checked and were normal A chest X-ray was obtained, and showed no pulmonary edema, effusions, or rib fractures, but did reveal a 2mm nodule in the right upper lobe.
Percocet was given for pain, presumed to be muscular strain from the accident.
BP 112/60, Pulse 60, Resp 16, Temp 96.7, sPO2 96% on RA

cda:code.displayName: EARS AND NOSE AND MOUTH AND THROAT, PHYSICAL FINDINGS

cda:paragraph.cda:content: Supple with normal range of motion.
Clear to auscultation and Percussion Bilateral.

cda:code.displayName: GENITOURINARY, HISTORY OF SYMPTOMS AND DISEASES

cda:paragraph.cda:content: Soft, Nontender, without mass or hepatospleenomegally.

cda:code.displayName: GENITOURINARY, HISTORY OF SYMPTOMS AND DISEASES
NEUROLOGIC SYSTEM, HISTORY OF SYMPTOMS AND DISEASES

cda:paragraph.cda:content: Grossly intact strength, sensation, reflexes and gait.
Chest X-ray shows no pulmonary edema, effusions, or rib fractures.
It did reveal a 2mm nodule in the right upper lobe.
The patient was instructed to follow up with a primary care physician on return and have repeat chest radiography in 3 months to evaluate the newly noted pulmonary nodule.
